#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Battle of Ludlow Street

#Text=Rarely was a more genuine tribute paid to entrancing girlhood than when Aubrey compelled himself , by sheer force of will and the ticking of his subconscious time-sense , to wake at six o'clock the next morning .
#Text=For this young man took sleep seriously and with a primitive zest .
#Text=It was to him almost a religious function .
#Text=As a minor poet has said , he " made sleep a career . "
#Text=But he did not know what train Roger might be taking , and he was determined not to miss him .
#Text=By a quarter after six he was seated in the Milwaukee Lunch ( which is never closed -- Open from Now Till the Judgment Day .
#Text=Tables for Ladies , as its sign says ) with a cup of coffee and corned beef hash .
#Text=In the mood of tender melancholy common to unaccustomed early rising he dwelt fondly on the thought of Titania , so near and yet so far away .
#Text=He had leisure to give free rein to these musings , for it was ten past seven before Roger appeared , hurrying toward the subway .
#Text=Aubrey followed at a discreet distance , taking care not to be observed .
#Text=The bookseller and his pursuer both boarded the eight o'clock train at the Pennsylvania Station , but in very different moods .
#Text=To Roger , this expedition was a frolic , pure and simple .
#Text=He had been tied down to the bookshop so long that a day 's excursion seemed too good to be true .
#Text=He bought two cigars -- an unusual luxury -- and let the morning paper lie unheeded in his lap as the train drummed over the Hackensack marshes .
#Text=He felt a good deal of pride in having been summoned to appraise the Oldham library .
#Text=Mr. Oldham was a very distinguished collector , a wealthy Philadelphia merchant whose choice Johnson , Lamb , Keats , and Blake items were the envy of connoisseurs all over the world .
#Text=Roger knew very well that there were many better-known dealers who would have jumped at the chance to examine the collection and pocket the appraiser 's fee .

#Text=The word that Roger had had by long distance telephone was that Mr. Oldham had decided to sell his collection , and before putting it to auction desired the advices of an expert as to the prices his items should command in the present state of the market .

#Text=And as Roger was not particularly conversant with current events in the world of rare books and manuscripts , he spent most of the trip in turning over some annotated catalogues of recent sales which Mr. Chapman had lent him .
#Text=" This invitation , " he said to himself , " confirms what I have always said , that the artist , in any line of work , will eventually be recognized above the mere tradesman .
